question: Quiet, missy! Cursed pirates sail these waters. You want to call 'em down on us?
answer: Mr. Gibbs. That will do.

question: She was singing about pirates. Bad luck to sing about pirates, with us mired in this unnatural fog-- mark my words.
answer: Consider them marked. On your way.

question: Elizabeth? Is everything all right? Are you decent?
answer: Yes -- yes.

question: Still abed at this hour? It's a beautiful day! I have a gift for you.
answer: It's -- beautiful. May I inquire as to the occasion?

question: Is an occasion necessary for a father to dote upon his daughter with gifts? Although...I did think you could wear it to the ceremony today.
answer: Ceremony?

question: Captain Norrington's promotion ceremony.
answer: I knew it.

question: Or, rather, Commodore Norrington...a fine gentleman, don't you think? He fancies you, you know. Elizabeth? How's it coming?
answer: Difficult ... to say.

question: I'm told that dress is the very latest fashion in London.
answer: Women in London must have learned to not breath.

question: Ah, Mr. Turner! It's good to see you again!
answer: Good day, sir. I have your order. The blade is folded steel. That's gold filigree laid into the handle. If I may - Perfectly balanced. The tang is nearly the full width of the blade..

question: Impressive. .. very impressive. Commodore Norrington will be pleased, I'm sure. Do pass my compliments on to your master.
answer: I shall. A craftsman is always pleased to hear his work is appreciated --

question: It's remarkable how often those two traits coincide. What do you say to three shillings, and we forget the name?
answer: This dock is off-limits to civilians.

question: Sorry, I didn't know. Some sort of to-do up at the fort, eh? You two weren't invited?
answer: No ... someone has to make sure this dock stays off-limits to civilians.

question: Right. Commodore Norrington.
answer: That's a fine goal, I'm sure ... But it seems to me a ship like that -- -- makes this one here just a wee superfluous.

question: Oh, the Dauntless is the power in these waters, true enough -- but there's no ship that can match the Interceptor for speed.
answer: That so? I've heard of one, supposed to be fast, nigh uncatchable ... the Black Pearl?

question: The Black Pearl is a real ship.
answer: No, it's not.

question: Yes it is. I've seen it. Yes.
answer: You've seen the Black Pearl?

question: Yes. Yes, I have. ... No .
answer: No.

question: But I've seen a ship with black sails. ... no.
answer: You! Get away from there! You don't have permission to be aboard there!

question: I'm sorry. It's just such a pretty boat. Ship.
answer: What's your name?

question: Smith.
answer: And no lies!

question: None? Very well. You've rumbled me. I confess
answer: I said, no lies. He's not telling the truth.

question: Aren't you going to save her? Sailors. Fine. Don't lose these.
answer: Not breathing.

question: Move.
answer: I never would have thought of that.

question: Right where I left you. Not where I left you. You're the one they're hunting. The pirate.
answer: You look familiar ... Have I ever threatened you before?

question: I've made a point of avoiding familiarity with pirates.
answer: Ah. Then it would be a shame to put a black mark on your record. So if you'll excuse me ... Do you think this is wise, boy? Crossing blades with a pirate?

question: You threatened Miss Swann.
answer: Only a little. You know what you're doing, I'll give you that ... Excellent form ... But how's your footwork? If I step here - Very good! And if I step again, you step again. . . Ta! That's a good trick. Except, once again, you are between me and the way out. And now you have no weapon. Who makes all these?

question: I do. And I practice with them. At least three hours a day.
answer: You need to find yourself a girl. Or maybe the reason you practice three hours a day is you've found one -- but can't get her?

question: No. I practice three hours a day so that when I meet a pirate ... I can kill him. You cheated.
answer: Pirate. Move away.

question: No.
answer: Move!

question: No. I can not just step aside and let you escape.
answer: You're lucky, boy -- this shot's not meant for you.

question: Has my daughter given you an answer yet?
answer: No. She hasn't.

question: Well, she had a taxing day... Ghastly weather tonight.
answer: Bleak. Very bleak.

question: What was that?
answer: Cannon fire!

question: Up there!
answer: Listen, Estrella -- they haven't seen you. Hide, and first chance, run for the fort .

question: We know you're here, poppet. Come out and we promise we won't hurt you. We will find you, poppet ... You've got something of ours, and it calls to us! The gold calls to us! Hello, poppet.
answer: Please, no ... Par. .. Parlay!

question: What?
answer: Parlay! I invoke the right of parlay! According to" the Code of the Brethren, set down by the pirates Morgan and Bartholomew, you must take me to your Captain!

question: I know the code.
answer: If an adversary demands parley, you can do them no harm until the parlay is complete.

question: This isn't the armory.
answer: Well, well... Look what we have here, Twigg. It's. Captain Sparrow.

question: Huh. Last time I saw you, you were all alone on a God-forsaken island, shrinking into the distance. I'd heard you'd gotten off, but I didn't believe it.
answer: Did you sprout little wings and flyaway?

question: I am here to --
answer: And you'll not lay a hand on those under the protection of parlay! My apologies, miss. As you were saying, before you were so rudely interrupted?

question: Captain Barbossa ... I have come to negotiate the cessation of hostilities against Port Royal.
answer: There was a lot of long words in there, miss, and we're not but humble pirates. What is it you want?

question: I want you to leave. And never come back.
answer: I am disinclined to acquiesce to your request. Means' No. '

question: Very well. I'll drop it!
answer: My holds are bursting with swag. That bit of shine matters to me ... Why?

question: Because it's what you're searching for. You've been searching for it for years. I recognize this ship.
answer: Did you, now?

question: Fine. I suppose if this is worthless, there's no reason to keep it.
answer: NO! You have a name, missy?

question: Elizabeth - Turner. I'm a maid in the governor's household. Barbossa reacts to the name Turner
answer: You've got sand, for a maid.

question: Thank you, sir.
answer: And how does a maid come to own a trinket such as that? A family heirloom, perhaps?

question: Of course. I didn't steal it, if that's what you mean.
answer: No, no, nothing like that. Very well. You hand that over, we'll put your town to our rudder and ne'er return.

question: Can I trust you?
answer: It's you who invoked the parlay! Believe me, Miss, you'd best hand it over, now... or these be the last friendly words you'll hear!

question: Our bargain. . ? Wait! You must return me to shore! According to the rules of the Order of the Brethren -
answer: First. Your return to shore was not part of our negotiations nor our agreement, and so I 'must' do nothing. Secondly

question: We could strike a bargain -
answer: No. The pirates who invaded this fort left Sparrow locked in his cell. Ergo, he is not their ally, and therefore of no value. We will determine their most likely course, and launch a search mission that sails with the tide.

question: That's not good enough. This is Elizabeth's life!
answer: Mr. Turner, this is not the time for rash actions. Do not make the mistake of thinking you are the only man here who loves Elizabeth. Now, go home.

question: Are you familiar with that ship? The Black Pearl?
answer: Somewhat.

question: Where does it make berth?
answer: Surely you've heard the stories? The Black Pearl sails from the dreaded Isla de Mureta... an island that cannot be found -- except by those who already know where it is.

question: The ship's real enough. So its anchorage must be a real place. Where is it?
answer: Why ask me?

question: Because you're a pirate.
answer: And you want to turn pirate yourself?

question: Never. They took Miss Swann.
answer: So it is that you found a girl. Well, if you're intending to brave all and hasten to her rescue and so win fair lady's heart, you'll have to do it alone. I see no profit in it for me.

question: I can get you out of here.
answer: How? The key's run off.

question: I helped build these cells. Those are hook-and-ring hinges. The proper application of strength, the door'll lift free. Just calls for the right lever and fulcrum. . .
answer: Your name is Turner.

question: Yes. Will Turner.
answer: Will Turner... I'll tell you what, Mr. Turner. I've changed my mind. You spring me from this cell, and on pain of death, I'll you to the Black Pearl. Do we have an accord?

question: Agreed.
answer: Agreed!

question: Someone will have heard that. Hurry.
answer: Not without my effects.

question: We need to go! Why are you bothering with that?
answer: My business, Will. As for your business -one question, or there's no use going. This girl -- what does she mean to you? How far are you willing to go to save her?

question: I'd die for her.
answer: Good. Ah, now there's a lovely sight! I knew the Harbormaster wouldn't report her. Honest men are slaves to their conscience, and there's no predicting 'em. But you can always trust a dishonest man to stay that way... Come aboard.

question: I haven't set foot off dry land I was twelve, when the ship I was on exploded. It's been a sound policy.
answer: No worries there. She's far more likely to rot out from under us. Besides, we are about to better our prospects considerably.

question: We're going to steal a ship? That ship?
answer: Commandeer. We're going to commandeer a ship. Nautical term.

question: It's still against the law.
answer: So's breaking a man out of jail. Face it, Will

question: This is either crazy, or brilliant.
answer: Remarkable how often those two traits coincide. Everybody stay calm. We're taking over the ship!

question: You're serious about this.
answer: Dead serious.

question: You understand this ship cannot be crewed by only two men. You'll never make it out of the bay.
answer: We'll see about that.

question: Sir, I'll not see any of my men killed or wounded in this foolish enterprise.
answer: Fine by me. We brought you a nice little boat, so you can all get back to shore, safe and sound.

question: Agreed. You have the momentary advantage, sir. But I will see you smile from the yard arm sir.
answer: As likely as not. Will, short up the anchor, we've got ourselves a ship! A little help?

question: Commodore --
answer: A moment.

question: But --
answer: Please.

question: Dammit, man, it appears someone is stealing your ship!
answer: Rash, Turner, too rash. That is, without doubt, the worst pirate I have ever seen.

question: Search every cabin, every hold, down to the bilges!
answer: Can you swim? Can. You. Swim? Good.

question: Sailors! Back to the Interceptor!
answer: Thank you, Commodore, for getting our ship ready to make way! We'd've had a hard time of it by ourselves!

question: Raise the sails.
answer: The wind is quarter from astern ... by the time we're underway, we'll never catch them.

question: We need only to come about, to put them in range of the long nines.
answer: Hands! Come about! Jackets off the cannons! We are to fire on our own ship?

question: Better to see it at the bottom of the sea than in the hands of a pirate. So it would seem.
answer: He's got to be the best pirate I've ever seen.

question: Maid or not, it fits you.
answer: Dare I ask the fate of its previous owner?

question: Now, none of that. Please dig in. No need to stand on ceremony, and no call to impress anyone. You must be hungry. Try the wine. And the apples -- one of those next.
answer: It's poisoned!

question: Oh, there would be no sense in killing you, Miss Turner.
answer: Then why aren't you eating?

question: Would that I could. Do you not know what this is, then?
answer: It's a pirate medallion.

question: It's a piece of the treasure of Isla de Muerta . Ah, so you don't know as much as you pretend. Back when Cortes was cutting a great bloody swath through the New World, a high priest gave. him all the gold they had, with one condition So the priest, with his dying breath, called on the power of the blood of his people, and put on the gold a curse. If anyone took so much as a single piece, as he was compelled by greed, by greed he would be consumed. Within a day of leaving port for Spain, the treasure ship carrying the gold ... something went wrong. The ship run aground, every man aboard dead, save one. He survived long enough to hide the gold ashore.
answer: That's all very interesting, but I hardly believe in ghost stories any more.

question: For a man whose made an industry of avoiding boats, you're a quick study.
answer: I worked passage from England as a cabin boy. After my mother passed, I came out here ... looking for my father.

question: Is that so?
answer: My father. William Turner? I'm not a simpleton. At the jail - - it was only after you learned my name that you agreed to help. Since that's what I wanted, I didn't press the matter. But now -

question: I knew him. Probably one of the few who knew him as William Turner. Most everyone just called him Bill, or 'Bootstrap' Bill.
answer: 'Bootstrap?'

question: Good man. Good pirate. And clever -"- I never met anyone with as clever a mind and hands as him. When you were puzzling out that cell door, it was like seeing his twin.
answer: That's not true.

question: I swear, you look just like him.
answer: It's not true that my father was a pirate.

question: Figured you wouldn't want to hear it.
answer: He was a merchant marine! He was a respectable man who obeyed the law, and followed the rules--

question: You think your father is the only man who ever lived the Glasgow life, telling folk one thing, and then going off to do another? There's quite a few who come here, hoping to amass enough swag to ease the burdens of respectable
answer: My father did not think of my mother -his family -- as a burden.

question: Sure -- because he could always go pirating.
answer: My father -- was not -- a pirate!

question: Put it away, Will. It's not worth getting beat again.
answer: You didn't beat me. You ignored the rules of engagement. In a fair fight, I'd kill you.

question: Then that's not much incentive for me to fight fair, is it? As long as you're just hanging there, pay attention. Must, Should, do, don't, shall, shall not -- those are just suggestions. There are only two absolute rules. What a man can do. And what a man can I t do. For instance
answer: Tortuga?

question: Oh -- did I forget to mention that? We need a crew. We can manage the ship between islands, but the open sea, that's another matter -
answer: Just do it quickly.

question: Don't worry. I've already got my Quartermaster -- there!
answer: You stole my boat.

question: AnaMaria! Have you seen Gibbs? I need to put together - Borrowed. Borrowed your boat. Without permission.
answer: My dory. The Jolly Mon. Where is it?

question: Safe! At Port Royal. With the Royal Navy.
answer: That boat is my livelihood!

question: You'll get it back. Or one better.
answer: I will.

question: Just the one.
answer: Make it_ast, then. Now, what's the nature of this venture of yours?

question: First -- have you found me a crew?
answer: Oh, there's a hard tale, Jack. Most of the decent pirates in town won't sail with you -- seem to think you're a jinx.

question: Now where, I wonder, would they have gotten that idea? I'm going after the Black Pearl.
answer: Say again?

question: Ilm going after the Black Pearl. I know where its going to be, and I'm going to take it.
answer: Jack, it's a fool's errand

question: Aye, and that's why I know where it's going to be, and that's why I know what Barbossa is up to. All I need is a crew.
answer: A fool's errand.

question: Not if the fool has something Barbossa wants. Something he needs.
answer: And you've got that, have you?

question: Back there, guarding the door is the son of old Bootstrap Bill Turner.
answer: Well, lookee there. I'll allow you may be onto something, Jack. There's bound to be sailors on this rock crazy as you. I'll find some men. Kid's a bit of a stick, isn't he?

question: That he is.
answer: Feast your eyes, Cap'n. All of 'em good sea-faring men, faithful hands before the mast, every one worth his salt --

question: These are the only ones worth having. And we're going to need them-
answer: That fool will have us lose the canvas, and the masts besides! Werd best drop canvas, sirl

question: She can hold a bit longer.
answer: What's in your head to put you in such a fine mood?

question: Left handed-ropes are coiled against the sun, or it's bad luck! Anty-clockwise.
answer: How do we expect to find an island no one can find -- with a compass that doesn't work?

question: Now, lad, just because it don't point north don't mean it don't work. That compass gives bearings to the Isla de Muerta, wherever it may lie.
answer: Really? So ... what's the story on the pistol?

question: I'll tell lee. Now, Jack Sparrow has an honest streak in him, and that's where the whole problem starts. This was when he was Captain of the Black Pearl -
answer: What? He never told me that.

question: Ah -- he's learned, then. Plays things more close to the vest. See, Jack was a cartographer, back in Old England. Somehow I he came by the money to commission the Pearl. Hired himself a crew, promised each man an equal share. So, they're forty days out, and the First Mate says, everything's an equal share, that should mean the location of the island, too. So Jack gave up the bearings. That night, there was mutiny. Jack gave hisself up for the sake of his loyal crewmen. He was marooned on an island, left there to die.
answer: How did he get off the island?

question: You?!
answer: Me!

question: You're in league with Barbossa!
answer: No, I'm -- rescuing you.

question: No. This won't work. I'll stay behind, and fight them. You go on.
answer: No.

question: I'll lead them away. Go to the opposite end of the island, and signal the ship. I'll keep 'em busy.
answer: Are you sure? Jack -- this is not something you have to do.

question: I'm sure. When you've led the kind of life I have, there are debts that must be paid. Maybe I can balance the scales a little. I invoke the right of parlay, according to the Code of the Brethren, set down by the pirates Morgan and Bartholomew...
answer: I'm inclined to kill you now, Jack Sparrow, without so much as a word, if you don't lose that grin from your face.

question: The woman's blood didn't work, did it? I know who's blood you need, to end the curse.
answer: Say the name, or I slit your throat.

question: Now. No, don't kill him. Allow me the humor of listening to your terms.
answer: Simple. I have something you want more than anything. The way to free you from the curse of the treasure. You have something I want -- more than anything.

question: The Pearl? Oh, that's fine. And just how do you expect this to work?
answer: You give me the Pearl. Then I tell you who you need.

question: That's your offer? You, sailing away nice and pretty with the Black Pearl, and all I have is a name?
answer: That's right.

question: I'm supposed to ... trust you?
answer: I'm a man of my word. You see, I've got this honest streak in me -- in its own way, a sort of curse. Oh, and there's the fact that you have no choice.

question: I'll torture it out of you.
answer: You left me on a desert island -- what worse can you do?

question: Blast you! I'll throw you in prison.
answer: Wait as long as you like.

question: You're setting me up for a double cross, you with the ship, and me with nothing more than your word!
answer: Let's say I tell you the wrong person. What would you do?

question: Track you down and -
answer: And if I tell you the truth, you become mortal, and you won't come near me because you know I'd kill you.

question: Jack, I don't trust you, and that's a fact. Never trust a smiling man, you can lay to that.
answer: See, that's where we're different. I trust you ... to do what it takes to get what you want.

question: You're playing this as close to the edge as any man, I'll give you that. Pintel ... set sail. If this fool plan is to work, we'll need the medallion, and that means catching the ship which brought 'em here.
answer: What -- you don't have the medallion?

question: That fool woman took it. You be careful around her, Jack -- she's pretty enough, she'll steal your heart -- but pure evil inside.
answer: I'll watch my back.

question: ... you were in danger ... so I took the medallion. And I've kept it ever since. They thought I was you, that they needed my blood. And it didn't work.
answer: Why would my father send this to me?

question: To keep it away from them? No pirate would sail to London, for fear of Execution Dock.
answer: If I had known-

question: -- then we never would have met.
answer: I can't believe he would make such a sacrifice for us.

question: Welcome back, Miss. Last time on board, you played me right clever, make pretending and all. I hope your stay this time is more pleasant. Boys, show her some hospitality!
answer: She goes free!

question: What's in your head, boy?
answer: She. Goes. Free.

question: You've got one shot -- and we can't die.
answer: You can't. I can.

question: Enough of that! Name your terms.
answer: Elizabeth goes free!

question: We got that part. Anything else?
answer: And Jack. And the crew. Free and unharmed. I f you agree... then... I will remain with you.

question: It's pure evil to make a Captain walk the plank of his own ship, twice in one lifetime. No good can come of it.
answer: Now, Jack. That reef is less than a league distant. It's a square deal all around, and you can't hope for better.

question: Someone needs to cut these bonds, then.
answer: You'd best take a swim, Jack.

question: By the Powers, you're right! Where's Jack's pistol? Who's got it? Bring it forward!
answer: A gentleman might give us two pistols, seeing as there are two of us, this time.

question: Tell you what. I'll give you one pistol, and let you be the gentleman, an' shoot the lady, and starve to death yourself! That is, presuming you're not both drownded. So how did you get off that island, anyway?
answer: You can go to your grave not knowing.

question: You went back for that? We need to head for the reef!
answer: That's the second time I've had to watch that man sail away with my ship. Not all that big, is it?

question: Has it changed since the last time you were here?
answer: The trees are taller.

question: I hope you have no intention of using that.
answer: Not yet. Ask me again in a few weeks.

question: Captain Sparrow! We have to get off this island -- immediately!
answer: Don't be thinking I'm not already working on it.

question: What is that? Is there a boat under there? What? What's wrong? How will this help us get off the island?
answer: It won't. It won't, and so we won't.

question: But ... you did it before! Last time -
answer: Last time, I was here a grand total of three days. Last time, the rumrunners who used this island as a cache came by, and I bartered passage off. But from the looks of this, they've long been'out of business, and so that won't be happening again. We probably have your friend Norrington to thank for that.

question: So that's it? That's the secret grand adventure of the infamous
answer: Welcome to the Caribbean, love. You should look at our contretemps this way

question: A month? Will doesn't have a month! We've got to do something to help him!
answer: You're right. Here's luck to you, Will Turner. Don't be thinking I'm happy about this, Elizabeth. But I see no use in wailing and gnashing my teeth over that which I can do nothing about.

question: Not when you can drink instead, at least.
answer: Try it. It goes down rough, but it goes down - - and the second swig goes down easier.

question: And you will call me Miss Swann. Drink up me hearties, yo ho...
answer: What? What was that? Something funny, Miss Swann? share. Please,

question: Nothing ... it's nothing. Just ... I'm reminded of a song I learned as a child. A song about pirates.
answer: I know a lot of songs about pirates, but none I'd teach a child. Let's hear it.

question: Oh, no ... it's silly. Back in England we didn't know a thing about pirates, really. They seemed so romantic and daring - That was before I met one, of course.
answer: Now I must hear this song. An authentic pirate song. Have at it.

question: Well, perhaps ... with a bit more to drink, I might ...
answer: More to drink! Well?

question: We pillage, we plunder, we rifle, we loot, Drink up me hearties, yo ho. We kidnap and ravage and we don't give a hoot, Drink up me hearties, yo ho -
answer: I LOVE this song! Yo ho, yo ho, a pirate's life for me! We're beggars and blighters, When I get the Black Pearl back, I'm going to teach it to the whole crew, and we'll sing it all the time!

question: You'll be positively the most fearsome pirates to sail the Spanish Main.
answer: Not just the Spanish Main. The whole ocean. .. the whole world. Wherever we want to go, we go. That's what a ship is, you know. Not just a keel and a hull and a deck and sails. That's what a ship need_ ... but what a ship is -- what the Black Pearl really-is ... is freedom.

question: Jack, it must be so terrible for you, to be trapped here on this island, all over again.
answer: Ah, well... the company is better than last time. And the scenery has definitely improved. We've got a few bottles left ... and we've yet to tap the kegs.

question: To freedom.
answer: To the Black Pearl. What are you doing? You've burned our food, the shade -- the rum!

question: Yes, the rum is gone.
answer: Why?

question: One, because it is a vile drink that turns even the most respectable men into scoundrels. Two - That signal is over a thousand feet high, which means it can be seen for two hundred leagues in every direction. The entire Royal Navy is out to sea looking for me -- do you think there is even a chance they could mass it?
answer: You -- you burned up the island, for a one-time chance at being spotted?

question: Exactly. Just you wait, Captain. In an hour, maybe two, keep a 'weather eye open' and you'll be seeing white sails on that horizon!
answer: They'll be no living with her after this.

question: By remembering that I serve others, not only myself.
answer: Commodore, I beg you -- please do this ... for me. As a wedding gift.

question: I am to understand that you will accept my marriage proposal on the condition I rescue Mr. Turner?
answer: Not as a condition -- a request.

question: Elizabeth, I hereby withdraw my proposal.
answer: What?

question: I know now where your heart truly lies.
answer: And now I know... where yours does, as well.

question: You may seclude yourself in my cabin. I'm afraid we do not have any ladies' clothing aboard.
answer: Then I can wear men's clothing.

question: That would hardly be proper.
answer: Well, I am not going to stay hidden in a some cabin, 80 I suppose it's going to be heaving bosoms and bare ankles for the remainder of the voyage!

question: That ain't going to work. That's the gun deck above yea
answer: What happened to William Turner?

question: Ah, William Turner. Stupid blighter. He threw in with us after we relieved Jack Sparrow of his captaincy, but turned out, it never sat well with him- particularly after we found Cortes' treasure, and its peculiar condition. He thought we deserved to be cursed, for leaving ol' Jack to the fate we did. That's why he sent off a piece of the treasure -- to you, as it were
answer: And then he ran. And he's hiding out someplace where you haven't been able to find him.

question: You didn't tell Commodore Norrington everything.
answer: Nor did you, I noticed.

question: He might delay the rescue ... and that would be too late.
answer: Exactly.

question: These men will be facing an enemy that seemingly cannot be killed.
answer: I have a plan. If it succeeds, then any battle will be decidedly brief ... and one-sided.

question: Elizabeth -- below decks. I will not compromise your safety.. Lieutenant, escort Elizabeth to my quarters, and make sure she stays there. I don't like the situation, mister Sparrow. The island is riddled with caves. I will not put my men at a disadvantage.
answer: Funny, I was thinking along those lines. How about you let me go in alone, and while you're setting up an ambush, I'll trick the pirates out to you.

question: You would do that?
answer: They left me stranded. Twice. What have you got to lose?

question: Nothing I wouldn't be please to be rid of.
answer: I knew you'd listen to reason! That chart I drew up'11 get you past the reefs. If you're steersman's good enough, that is.

question: I'll be at the wheel myself.
answer: I'll slip in, talk them into to come out, and you'll be free to blow holy high heaven the whole lot of them.

question: Do you have any idea where you're going?
answer: Jack!

question: Don't talk. These caves magnify sound. Just follow me.
answer: Are you certain this is the right way?

question: What was begun by blood, let blood now end!
answer: You don't want to be doing that.

question: No, I really think I do.
answer: All right then.

question: Why don't I want to do this?
answer: Because, right about now, the H.M.S. Dauntless is lying in wait in the harbor.

question: No. But him I believe. He is genuinely angry.
answer: You've no hope of surviving Norrington's attack ... that is, if you're mortal.

question: What're you suggesting?
answer: Simple. Don't kill the boy yet. Wait for a more opportune moment. Like after you've killed... Every... Last ... One ... of Norrington's men.

question: I can't help wondering, Jack, why you're being so helpful and all? Last time you did that, it didn't end 80 well for you.
answer: The situation has changed.

question: That so?
answer: Aye. See, after you're done with the Royal Navy, you'll have a bit of a problem I sail for you as part of your fleet, I give you fifteen percent of my plunder, and you get to introduce yourself at tea parties and brothels as 'Commodore Barbossa.' Do we have an accord? Now, you can take care of the Dauntless, right?

question: Men! Are you up for it? Mr. Pintel, select five men to stay here. Take the rest of the men out ... not through the caves.
answer: There's ... another exit?

question: Let's get out of here.
answer: You're all right!

question: Miss Swann -- are you wearing trousers? And how did you get off the island?
answer: Yes, I am wearing trousers. And as for how we got off the island -- ah, that's a grand adventure, but now is not the time to talk about it. There. And don't you dare tell me that wasn't a proper kiss!

question: Elizabeth, I think it doesn't matter- that we are of a different class -
answer: It doesn't!
